ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned rigorous theory behind supply, demand, utility and production very well. My problem solving skills also certainly improved.

A whole lot of microeconomics. Before the midterm, we covered preferences, utilities, Marshallian and Hicksian demand, duality, nonlinear programming, and choice under uncertainty for consumers. After, we did firms and production, general equilibrium, partial equilibrium, and then mechanism design.
Microeconomic theory. Due to poor teaching of this course, I don't know how much I gained from the professor vs. personal studying.
A better understanding of the fundamental principles of micro. It is much more mathematically rigorous.
This course is intended to mimic the first microeconomics course you would take in grad school except it is probably much easier and lower expectations.
This course helped to generalize economics concepts and remove earlier assumptions made in intro micro.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Topics were really interesting and rigorously presented and proven. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes the lectures were a bit fast and confusing

Strengths: very rigorous. The professor was very kind and helpful during office hours. He had not taught the class before, so he didn't have any practice exams, but for the midterm and final, he gave us a ton of questions and solutions. Also, during class, if not interrupted, he would mix rigorous proof with economic intuition pretty well. Weaknesses: the syllabus is way too ambitious. Absolutely no one had any idea what was going on when we did mechanism design. I think it would be better for us to go more carefully through general and partial equilibrium and save mechanism design for a game theory class. In that regard, although I enjoyed the mathematical rigor, I kind of wished there was more economics to this class. At times, it just felt like we were solving some messy math problem. Also, more class organization would be better. For example, making sure psets were released at consistent times would make the class run much mroe smoothly. Also, I think this class should really have weekly psets. I don't think I got enough practice. Finally, this might be an economics thing, but the notation defies logic (example: the cost function labeled c(x) included a constant c).

This course is terribly designed. The only listed prerequisite is Math 120. However, knowledge of real analysis (boundedness of sets) and linear algebra (hessian matrices, negative semi-definiteness) is frequently an important part of both the conceptual knowledge and the problem sets. The course lacks clear goals and fails to explain the importance of any concepts in microeconomic theory. Furthermore, both the professor and the teaching fellow lacked a strong understanding of the material and were unable to answer simple student questions. The pacing of this course is also way to quick. The vast majority of students felt like they were being left behind and didn't appreciate any of the concepts learned. Lectures in class were an exercise in trying to pick through hand-waving for any sensible statement.
Material in class was not explained super clearly, sometimes it went too fast, other times it went to slow; overall just hard to follow

The course at times just felt like doing math for maths sake. Often the economic motivations were not explored in the detail that I would have enjoyed. I think that the treatment of topics was satisfactory, but I wish that problem sets and lectures were slightly more focused on the "why do we care" questions.
The lectures at times were pretty good but could also be hard to follow at times. The textbook was also hard to digest.
Material was very difficult, especially towards the end, and not always explained very well. Though the topics were interesting, they were not made particularly accessible.

This course was very interesting and valuable but I felt that it was more difficult than it needed to be, and we were assumed to have a level of previous knowledge that didn't align with the listed prerequisites. Obviously micro theory is going to be very theoretical, but I think this course could be stronger if some more motivation was given for why we were proving or learning the things we were.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interested really learning microeconomics, then 100% yes. If you do not have a strong background in mathematics though, it may be a bit tough.

Yeah, if they want to know the basic foundations of micro-economics. In that regard, the beginning definitely feels like a real analysis class, so you might want to get some exposure to that before taking the class.
Do not take this course unless it is drastically overhauled. Many excellent students in this class are dropping economics from their joint majors because of this course.
Lecture was difficult to follow and ended up having to do a lot of learning on my own. Would not recommend this class.

If you really want to go to econ grad school then you should take it. It is not particularly interesting. I don't think that I fundamentally understand microeconomics better after this class. I mostly just practiced annoying mathematical techniques like langrangians.

I would recommend only in the case you are passionate about economics and think you want to go to econ grad school.  If you are interested otherwise you should shop alongside intermediate micro and make up your mind that way

If you take this course, expect to do a lot of learning on your own. For me, that meant reading from three textbooks to understand what was going on in lecture (Jehle and Reny, MWG, and Varian). Further, the listed prereqs are a bit misleading: some understanding of real analysis is quite important for this class.
I would recommend this course to a student who has a strong math background and wants to go to econ grad school.
